questions.text: A 17-year-old girl comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of severe itching in the area of her genitals. She reports that the itching is most severe at night. She has been sexually active with three partners over the past year; she uses condoms for contraception. Her current sexual partner is experiencing similar symptoms. Pelvic examination shows vulvar excoriations. A photomicrograph of an epilated pubic hair is shown. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Infestation with the parasite Phthirus pubis causes pediculosis pubis, an infection that manifests with anogenital pruritus. Pediculosis pubis is a sexually transmitted infection that is not prevented by condoms. Physical examination of the pubic area typically shows excoriations as well as lice, their nits, and their droppings, which are visible both with the naked eye and on microscopy, as seen in the photomicrograph here.

B) INCORRECT:

Infestation with Pediculus humanus causes pediculosis capitis or pediculosis corporis, which also manifest with pruritus and excoriations. However, this patient's signs and symptoms are limited to the genital area, making a head or body lice infestation unlikely. Additionally, nits of Pediculus humanus corporis attach to clothes and nits of Pediculus humanus capitis attach to scalp hair shafts, whereas the photomicrograph here shows a nit attached to a pubic hair.

C) INCORRECT:

The roundworm Enterobius vermicularis causes enterobiasis, which may also manifest with anogenital pruritus that is most severe at night. Eggs are transmitted through the fecal-oral route, typically via contaminated hands or during sexual intercourse, which is why close contacts of infected patients are often also affected. However, this patient's photomicrograph shows a nit attached to a shaft of a pubic hair, which is not typical for E. vermicularis. Enterobiasis is instead diagnosed through direct visualization of mobile worms in the perianal region or with a positive tape test, in which eggs of the worm are visible.
Image Description:

Two pinworms (Enterobius vermicularis) in a stool sample.

D) INCORRECT:

Dermatophytes like Epidermophyton floccosum cause diseases such as tinea pedis, tinea cruris, tinea corporis, and onychomycosis. While tinea cruris can manifest with pruritus and excoriations in the genital area, typical skin findings include an area of centrifugally growing, circular erythema, which is not described in this patient. Additionally, dermatophyte infections will show hyphae on microscopy, while the photomicrograph here shows an organism attached to a pubic hair.
Image Description:

There is well-demarcated erythema with a raised border visible around the scrotum and upper thighs of the patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Infestation with Sarcoptes scabiei causes scabies, a highly contagious infection transmitted through skin-to-skin contact (e.g., sexual intercourse). Although typical findings include pruritus and excoriations, scabies most commonly manifests with papules, vesicles, and burrow tracks on the wrists and intertriginous regions rather than the genital area. Furthermore, unlike the organism seen in the photomicrograph here, Sarcoptes scabiei mites do not attach to pubic hair.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a human itch mite (Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis)

Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis, the mite that causes scabies, has a round body and four pairs of legs (green overlay): The front legs end in suckers, while the hind legs end in long bristles. Between the medial front legs, the scabies mite has a mouthpart (red overlay) that it uses for burrowing into the host's skin. Between the medial posterior pairs of legs, the anus of the mite is visible (yellow overlay), from which the female mites lay eggs in the skin's stratum corneum.
questions.hint: The photomicrograph shows a nit attached to the hair shaft.

questions.text:
As the health consultant for a local elementary school, you are helping to develop evidence-based lice-mitigation protocols for the school.
The administration is debating how the school should respond when a child presents to the nurse’s office with scalp pruritus and is found to have live lice or nits on the hair shaft.
In addition to notifying the child’s parents, which one of the following interventions is most appropriate for managing classroom spread of lice in this situation?

choices.text: Return the child to the classroom, advising them to avoid head-to-head contact with others
Have the nurse apply dimethicone and then send the child home, with a plan to have a parent or guardian remove the dimethicone in 8 hours and send the child back to school the next day
Send the child home with instructions to return to school after treatment with permethrin
Exclude the child from school while live lice are present, but allow them to return when only nits remain
Recommend treatment of all of the child’s close classroom contacts

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Pediculosis capitis (head lice) is a common pediatric ectoparasite infestation. Although this organism is not a vector for morbidity-causing disease, it is quite contagious and frequently causes children to miss school. A case of head lice is diagnosed clinically when live adult lice are noted in the hair or nits are observed on the hair shafts. Nits are lice eggs or egg casings that are attached to hair shafts when laid.

Most viable nits are found within a few millimeters of the scalp. Visual inspection alone has an approximate diagnostic accuracy of 95%. Accuracy may increase to more than 99% when the hair is wet and combed to remove knots and tangles, and then a fine-tooth comb (teeth spaced <0.5 mm apart) is passed through the hair. Visual inspection for live lice and nits should be made after each comb stroke.

Head lice are transmitted through direct person-to-person contact, typically head-to-head touching. Itching, a classic symptom of lice infestation, does not typically develop until after several weeks of exposure to lice saliva, so infestation is likely to have occurred well before symptom onset. Children with head lice therefore need not be immediately excluded from school upon diagnosis, although some mitigation measures may be considered (including avoiding head-to-head contact between the affected child and other children until after treatment is completed). A symptomatic child’s parents should be notified so that they can examine the child, treat them at home, and carefully inspect all household members for lice and nits.

The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends treatment with topical pyrethroids (such as permethrin or pyrethrins) as first-line therapy for head lice, except when there is evidence of local resistance or in cases of failed therapy. Ten days after the first application of treatment (the typical incubation period for eggs to hatch), a second application should be made if needed. If families are hesitant to use pediculicides or those agents have been ineffective in treating a given infestation, manual removal of lice and nits, as well as occlusive treatments such as the application of dimethicone and other alternatives, can be considered.

Key learning point: Children who experience an infestation of head lice should not be excluded from school or from child-care settings.

B) INCORRECT:

The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends treatment with topical pyrethroids (such as permethrin or pyrethrins) as first-line therapy for head lice, except when there is evidence of local resistance or in cases of failed therapy. If families are hesitant to use pediculicides or those agents have been ineffective in treating a given infestation, manual removal of lice and nits, as well as occlusive treatments such as the application of dimethicone and other alternatives, can be considered.

C) INCORRECT:

The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends treatment with topical pyrethroids (such as permethrin or pyrethrins) as first-line therapy for head lice, except when there is evidence of local resistance or in cases of failed therapy. Ten days after the first application of treatment (the typical incubation period for eggs to hatch), a second application should be made if needed. If families are hesitant to use pediculicides or those agents have been ineffective in treating a given infestation, manual removal of lice and nits, as well as occlusive treatments such as the application of dimethicone and other alternatives, can be considered. Children with head lice therefore need not be immediately excluded from school upon diagnosis, although some mitigation measures may be considered (including avoiding head-to-head contact between the affected child and other children until after treatment is completed). Children with head lice therefore need not be immediately excluded from school upon diagnosis, although some mitigation measures may be considered.

D) INCORRECT:

Children who are found to have nits alone should also not be excluded from the classroom. Many of these children will not develop an infestation of live lice, and even if they do, they should not be excluded. Children with head lice should not be stigmatized, and returning them to the classroom can help with this.

E) INCORRECT:

Head lice are transmitted through direct person-to-person contact, typically head-to-head touching. Itching, a classic symptom of lice infestation, does not typically develop until after several weeks of exposure to lice saliva, so infestation is likely to have occurred well before symptom onset. . A symptomatic child’s parents should be notified so that they can examine the child, treat them at home, and carefully inspect all household members for lice and nits.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl comes to your clinic with a 1-week history of severe itching in the genital area, which is most intense at night. She has been sexually active with three partners over the past year and uses condoms for contraception. Her current sexual partner is experiencing similar symptoms. On pelvic examination, there are vulvar excoriations. A photomicrograph of an epilated pubic hair is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dermatophytes like Epidermophyton floccosum cause diseases such as tinea pedis, tinea cruris, tinea corporis, and onychomycosis. While tinea cruris can manifest with pruritus and excoriations in the genital area, typical skin findings include an area of centrifugally growing, circular erythema, which is not described in this patient. Additionally, dermatophyte infections will show hyphae on microscopy, while the photomicrograph here shows an organism attached to a pubic hair.

B) INCORRECT:

Infestation with Pediculus humanus causes pediculosis capitis or pediculosis corporis, which also manifest with pruritus and excoriations. However, this patient's signs and symptoms are limited to the genital area, making a head or body lice infestation unlikely. Additionally, nits of Pediculus humanus corporis attach to clothes and nits of Pediculus humanus capitis attach to scalp hair shafts, whereas the photomicrograph here shows a nit attached to a pubic hair.

C) INCORRECT:

The roundworm Enterobius vermicularis causes enterobiasis, which may also manifest with anogenital pruritus that is most severe at night. Eggs are transmitted through the fecal-oral route, typically via contaminated hands or during sexual intercourse, which is why close contacts of infected patients are often also affected. However, this patient's photomicrograph shows a nit attached to a shaft of a pubic hair, which is not typical for E. vermicularis. Enterobiasis is instead diagnosed through direct visualization of mobile worms in the perianal region or with a positive tape test, in which eggs of the worm are visible.

D) CORRECT:

Infestation with the parasite Phthirus pubis causes pediculosis pubis, an infection that manifests with anogenital pruritus. Pediculosis pubis is a sexually transmitted infection that is not prevented by condoms. Physical examination of the pubic area typically shows excoriations as well as lice, their nits, and their droppings, which are visible both with the naked eye and on microscopy, as seen in the photomicrograph here.

Key learning point: Pediculosis pubis is a sexually transmitted infestation caused by Phthirus pubis, presenting with intense genital itching and nits attached to pubic hair.

E) INCORRECT:

Infestation with Sarcoptes scabiei causes scabies, a highly contagious infection transmitted through skin-to-skin contact (e.g., sexual intercourse). Although typical findings include pruritus and excoriations, scabies most commonly manifests with papules, vesicles, and burrow tracks on the wrists and intertriginous regions rather than the genital area. Furthermore, unlike the organism seen in the photomicrograph here, Sarcoptes scabiei mites do not attach to pubic hair.
questions.hint: The photomicrograph shows a nit attached to the hair shaft.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother with a 10-day history of intense scalp pruritus and scratching. The mother reports finding small white specks in his hair and states that three classmates were recently sent home from school for lice. Physical examination shows multiple excoriations on the scalp and several small, oval, white-colored structures firmly attached to hair shafts 3–4 mm from the scalp root. No mobile insects are visualized during examination. The child appears well with normal vital signs. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Recommend fine-tooth comb removal and follow-up
Perform more thorough examination for viable lice

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dermatology consultation is not indicated for suspected lice infestation, which can be diagnosed and managed in the emergency department.

B) INCORRECT:

Mechanical removal with fine-tooth comb is an adjunctive treatment measure, but the diagnosis must first be confirmed by identifying viable lice. The presence of nits alone is insufficient for diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Treatment should not be initiated before diagnosis is confirmed. The white structures observed are likely nits, but diagnosis of active head lice infestation requires identification of at least one viable louse before treatment can be recommended.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral ivermectin is an alternative treatment option for head lice but should only be initiated after confirming the diagnosis by identifying at least one viable louse. Nits alone do not confirm active infestation.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- The diagnosis of head lice infestation requires visualization of at least one viable louse, not just nits. While the white structures are likely nits and clinical history suggests lice, a more thorough examination of the scalp and hair, particularly in the retroauricular area and nape (where lice are easier to detect), is needed to confirm active infestation before initiating treatment.
